sen.j: 丹羽 正伯（にわ しょうはく、元禄4年（1691年） - 宝暦6年4月14日 (旧暦)（1756年5月12日））は、江戸中期を代表する本草学者である。
sen.e: Shohaku NIWA (1691 - May 12, 1756) was a notable scholar of herbalism in mid Edo period.

sen.j: 伊勢国松阪（現・三重県松阪市）に生まれた医者である。
sen.e: He was born in Matsuzaka, Ise province (present Matsusaka City, Mie Prefecture) and a doctor.

sen.j: 本草学を京都の稲生若水に学び、後に江戸幕府の採薬使に登用される。
sen.e: He learnt herbalism from Jakusui INOU in Kyoto, and later he was appointed to Saiyakushi (a person who gathers medicinal herbs in the fields and mountain) in Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

sen.j: 野呂元丈・植村政勝らと各地の採薬調査を行う傍ら、下総薬園の管理、薬草の栽培を命じられた。
sen.e: He was ordered to undertake Saiyaku (to gather medicinal herbs in the fields and mountain) research in various regions with Genjo NORO and Masakatsu UEMURA, as well as to manage and cultivate herbs in Shimousa medicinal-herb garden.

He was ordered to undertake Saiyaku (to gather medicinal herbs in the fields and mountain) research in various regions with Genjo NORO and Masakatsu UEMURA, as well as to manage Shimousa Yakuen (medicinal-herb garden) and cultivate herbs there.
sen.cmt: manage の目的語は「下総薬園」,cultivateの目的語は「薬草」であることを明確にしました。また次の文との関係で「薬園」をYakuenとしました。
sen.e: He was ordered to undertake Saiyaku (to gather medicinal herbs in the fields and mountain) research in various regions with Genjo NORO and Masakatsu UEMURA, as well as to manage Shimousa Yakuen (medicinal-herb garden) and cultivate herbs there.

sen.j: なお、正伯が管理をしていた下総滝台野薬園(現・千葉県船橋市薬円台)がその後、同地の地名の由来となった。
sen.e: Shimousa Takidaino medicinal-herb garden (present Yakuendai, Funabashi City, Chiba Prefecture) that was managed by Shohaku later became the origin of a place-name.
The name of the place (present Yakuendai, Funabashi City, Chiba Prefecture) in which Shimousa Takidaino Yakuen (medicinal-herb garden) managed by Shohaku was located is derived from the garden.
sen.cmt: 文末のthe origin of a place-nameでは「同地」の意味が訳出できず、全体の意味も判りにくいので書き換えました。
sen.e: The name of the place (present Yakuendai, Funabashi City, Chiba Prefecture) in which Shimousa Takidaino Yakuen (medicinal-herb garden) managed by Shohaku was located is derived from the garden.

sen.j: また、彼の功績を称え、「薬園台」を地域では別名「正伯新田」という呼称もあり、古地図にも記されている。
sen.e: Also there is another name of 'Yakuendai' that is 'Shohaku Nitta' to praise his great achievement and the name is also written in old map.
In the region, the place 'Yakuendai' is also called by another name 'Shohaku Shinden' in honor of Shohaku's great achievement, and the name appears in some old maps.
sen.cmt: 「新田」をShinden としました。 全体の流れも自然な流れになるよう書き換えました
sen.e: In the region, the place 'Yakuendai' is also called by another name 'Shohaku Shinden' in honor of Shohaku's great achievement, and the name appears in some old maps.

sen.j: 主な著書は、若水から引き継いだ本草学書「庶物類纂」や全国の動植物、鉱物等産物を網羅的に調査した「諸国産物帳」などがある。
sen.e: Notable books that he wrote were Honsogakusho (a book on the study of herbalism), 'Shobutsuruisan (a book on the study of herbalism)', which he took over from Jakusui, and 'Shokoku sanbutsucho' that includes researches on various plants and minerals from all over Japan.

Notable books written by Shohaku include 'Shobutsuruisan', a book of herbalism he took over from Jakusui, and 'Shokoku sanbutsucho', a book describing results of his exhaustive researches on various plants, animals and minerals from all over Japan.
sen.cmt: 「本草学」はローマ字表記する必要のない単語であり普通に英訳するのみとしました。後半は「動物」「網羅」が訳出されていなかったので、書き加えました。
sen.e: Notable books written by Shohaku include 'Shobutsuruisan', a book of herbalism he took over from Jakusui, and 'Shokoku sanbutsucho', a book describing results of his exhaustive researches on various plants, animals and minerals from all over Japan.

sen.j: 正伯は宝暦6年に江戸で没した。
sen.e: Shohaku died in 1756 in Edo.

sen.j: 後に薬園台村の人びとにより、顕彰の供養碑が建てられ、その正面には諦通院日慮と刻まれている。
sen.e: Later his monument of kensho (honor a person publicly for an unrecognized good deed) was founded by people in Yakuendai village and its front is carved with 諦通院日慮 (his homyo (a Buddhist name given to a person who has died or has entered the priesthood)).

sen.e: Later, people in Yakuendai-mura village founded a monument for honoring his achievements, and inscribed on the front of the monument is "Taitsu-in Nichiryo" (Shohaku's posthumous Buddhist name).
sen.cmt: 「顕彰」はローマ字表記する必要のない単語であり普通に英訳するのみとし、法名の説明を簡略化しました。なお,「日慮」は読み方不明です。
